content: Now many years later, Viet Nam Veterans, are still treated like 2nd class Veterans, America has turned their backs on Us, the American Veterans fighting this War are treated like Hero's, we where treated baby Killers and All of us Veterans Are fighting the same War People Die, Men, Women, Children, and Babys, One is in a Jungle the other is in a Desert, Look at WWII and Korea, they all came home was Reat like Heros, and Also America Has Turned their Back on our Homeless Viet Nam Era Veteran and they act its not there Problem, we Are Americans we lokk after each other

You do not hear how EX IRAQI VET kills family then self. I could have swore I just heard something on the news the other day about an Iraq War Vet killing 5 other Veterans in Iraq. Maybe I'm wrong. ============================================= You did hear that and also I heard about one Iraq vet killed his wife. So they do repeort it. I went to Viet Nam 3 times and not once was I ever welcomed home. I felt like I should have stayed over there because of my service I was no longer wanted here. But things have changed some and I will agree I don't feel like our hero's of today. But I can honestly say I don't feel like a 2nd class citizen anymore, God Bless America and all it's fighting forces and that includes support personnel. SEABEE'S "CAN DO", "HAVE DONE", AND WILL DO SO FOREVER. GOD BLESS AMERICA

title: Viet Nam Era Veterans

content: Korea was, indeed, the "forgotten war." The veterans came home to no parades, no honors. They just came home. At least there was no active opposition to them - their peers were too busy getting on with life after WWII to notice them. VN vets faced hostility abroad and hostility at home - draftees or volunteers, men or women, we were all universally disparaged. With luck, those days are behind us and is DOES seem like we have learned this lesson: if there is blame, place it on the policy-makers, not the military. I think it took Desert Storm to drive that message home so that it stuck. Of course, it helped that the "war" lasted a whole 100 hours ... Whatever, those who died in service are worthy of remembrance and honor, no matter when or where. Salute to all of you men and women who died in service to our country.
reply: Korea was, indeed, the "forgotten war." The veterans came home to no parades, no honors. They just came home. At least there was no active opposition to them - their peers were too busy getting on with life after WWII to notice them. VN vets faced hostility abroad and hostility at home - draftees or volunteers, men or women, we were all universally disparaged. With luck, those days are behind us and is DOES seem like we have learned this lesson: if there is blame, place it on the policy-makers, not the military. I think it took Desert Storm to drive that message home so that it stuck. Of course, it helped that the "war" lasted a whole 100 hours ... Whatever, those who died in service are worthy of remembrance and honor, no matter when or where. Salute to all of you men and women who died in service to our country.

content: I'll weigh in as a 2-time OIF vet. While we don't have people spitting on us or callin gus baby killers(alhtough it does happen in isolated cases), the thing that makes me mad, is th emedia or anyone, talking about the war, and they have never been there. I do think people learned theri lesson from Vn, but I also think they hide it better. Look at teh soldiers burned in effigy in Portland a few years ago, or the DAV from OIF, that was spit on. There will always be douch bags out there, no matter what. To the OP, sounds like you need to talk to someone brother. Long time to hold your feelings on this in. I know it can be hard, but talk to someone about it, I sense soem hostility still, don't let it eat you up.
reply: I'll weigh in as a 2-time OIF vet. content: quote: Originally posted by MrKWilde: Now many years later, Viet Nam Veterans, are still treated like 2nd class Veterans, America has turned their backs on Us, the American Veterans fighting this War are treated like Hero's, we where treated baby Killers and All of us Veterans Are fighting the same War People Die, Men, Women, Children, and Babys, One is in a Jungle the other is in a Desert, Look at WWII and Korea, they all came home was Reat like Heros, and Also America Has Turned their Back on our Homeless Viet Nam Era Veteran and they act its not there Problem, we Are Americans we lokk after each other I have felt this way for Vietnam Vets and Korean Vets for a long time. Seeing it as a kid and even how the American general in public treated "them" and experiencing some of that unfounded, imo, personal luggage some Americans dropped on active duty servicemembers, in my era 1976-1978. Vets have been getting the "short end of the stick" forever,imo, it is a sad reality. Best advice I could give is talk it out with those you trust. By the time some Agent Orange vets were compensated and recognized, many were dead or had debilitating dieases. Our Korean vets with frostbite. Sad. Welcome home and thank you for your service. Robert
